Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2009 08:33AM denise1962 wrote: Nolagal They supposely last for two months. Somedays are better than others getting them on correctly. Sometimes they stay on for 2 days I have had them on up to 5 days at a time. I use a q-tip to remove the adhesive and then wash in wig shampoo. You can trim them but be very, very very careful as bugs bunny friend would say( can't remember his name)  I have order the strip eyelashes in a brown as the black ones looked like Carol Channing. I am also order the stencils to try. It does take me about 20 mins to attach the human hair so I want to see if the stencils will be quicker. Nolaga loved the stories of you father way too funny.

Posts.Content: denise1962 wrote: I posted before about the reaction to carboplatin reaction that I had durning my last infusion which was intense itching palms and sole of feet and peri anal region. then I started vomiitng and passing out. The nurses gave me meds to stop the reaction and slowed down the drip way down... Any way I belive that was cycle 8.  Of course I could't sleep last night and was looking up the side effects. Guess what this is pretty normal in about 10 percent of the cases. The problem is usually after a reaction like this the change to some other chemo. So I go in this thursday for my next infusion and was wondering if someone might know which chemo they will be switching me too. The other chemo is taxotere that I get along with Zometa. I also have another bump growing on my chest, just like the one found in July 07, the took me in for surgery for that one but don't know if they will for this one. My poor chest looks like mincemeat  LOL. So if anyone has any ideas or been there done that please share. Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2009 06:17PM denise1962 wrote: I think it could go like this: If you have priviate ins or cobra they are your primary. The if you go on medicare they become your secondary. Or you could go on medicare and they become your pirmary, then you could pick up AARP for a secondary. At least this is my understanding. I do beleive that if you do not go on medicare and deciede to go on later it is more expenesive. So if it was me I would keep my private ins, the go on medicare and apply for AARP which is always go to be secondary to medicare or private ins. Hope this helps Denise

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2008 08:38AM denise1962 wrote: Not to scare you, but I would get a scan done. I had chest pain for two months. First I thought I had pulled a muscle as I had just had a scan done which showed nothing. I waited to see if it would get better but it just got worse with pain in my upper back and going all the way around in front of my chest. Did get a xray but it didn't show nothing. After another month of this pain my pcp suggested I see my onoclolgist. I was able to get in the same day. Also had found a bb size lump on my mast scar. Needless to say went in for surgery that day and had a scan. Mets to pelvis, spine, liver, and chest wall.  This all happen in two months first a clean scan and then progression of mets. Please get it check! I will be saying a prayer that all is negative!! Denise

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2009 12:41PM denise1962 wrote: I would make an appt to go in and see him. Let him know that as far as the insurance co is concern it is a best guess and if you live longer than the 12 mos you do not have to pay the money back and they do not go after the doc. This is what my insurance co told me. Also I would send copies of scans, notes, labs for the last 6 mos. I personally asked my doc to mail all of this information to me so I could look over everything and make sure it was in order before I fed-ex it to the insurance co. Go luck Then I would run and find another doc.

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2009 04:17PM denise1962 wrote: I have a great husband who takes good care of me. I have let go of the little stuff, messes house ect,ect. But the way our medical team treats us just seems to get worse the further along in progression of stage V  goes. I went into our clinc today to get rehydration and had to sit outside literaly for an hour I was ok with this as I didn't feel like doing anything. Now this doc has seen me since bov 08 for hydration. I told him I drank 48 oz yesterday and he said not enough. Just when I went to tell him I have a standing order for a cbc he walks off and throws my chart on the counter. So I wait until the nurse comes in and tell her that I want a cbc added. Knowing she can draw the cbc after the IV is in. She replied no she would have to do them seperate. She never did. Luckly I got the lab tech to draw the cbc. But my point is it should have only been one stick. Also the was no charting done by the nurse. I will be courious  to see how she fills in the blanks later. Now these are people who I have spent the last 5 years working with. So I think yes people do treat us differently. And I don't like it.

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2008 11:34PM denise1962 wrote: Hi Kelly I had a liver biopsy 2 years ago, when I was going to donate a lobe to my brother. It wasn't really that painful. More like the wind being knocked out of you. They did have to do it twice, but like I said it was't painful. The hardest part was lying on the side where your liver is for 4-5 hrs. They do not want you to move around as that might start the liver to bleed. they will take your blood before the biopsy and at least one more time, but I think it was twice. The following day the nurse will call and see how you are feeling. No exercise or house cleaning for the first 24 hrs. Hope this helps and let us know how your test comes out. Big hugs denise

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2008 10:09AM denise1962 wrote: Hi CalGal I will try this again, I wrote every thing out and the dang server kicked me off. I was diagonised may 2006 with er pr her postive with her expressing at around 90%. I belevie 17 out of 21 nodes postive. Had bilateral mast chemo rads hercerptin and Arimadex. My last  pet/ct scan on 3-31-08 was completely negative. I have been having pressure on my chest which my primary doc did a chest xray for and showed nothing 3 weeks ago. I was thinking maybe a hernia. The when the pressure moved to the other side last week I went back to the primary doc and show her the bb size bump that had showed up along the scar line the side with the cancer. This appeared within a couple of days. She thought I was popping a stitch. but suggested I call my bc surgeon. who was able to get me in within 3 hrs. She took me into surgery that day a did a biopsy all the way to the chest wall. This is last monday. Tuesday it came back postive. went for a pet/ct scan on thursday. Got results back later that day. Postive to clavical. inner ribs. along the spine liver and pelvis bones. Not to mention it showed up in numerous lymph nodes though out these areas. Called the onc this morning and she went and talked to the radiologits who said he had never seen this happen before. I onco doc is starting chemo tomarrow because it appers to be multipling very quickly. I don't think I am being too arlarmed at this point because the reaction of the onco and radiologist think we need to move now. I am going to fight this second round with everything I got, but at the same time I would like all of my ducks in a row. Thank you CalGal I have followed your post and advice since I joined. Denise
